From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi Davij,

On 25 April 2017 at 02:07, divij_sood@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
> 1) Is there some easy way to visualize the Neural Networks evolved by NEAT? [...]
> I found this post on the group discussions, but I couldn't see the attached file
> that was referred to.

I've just the attachment to you in another email. In principle these
attachments appear in the yahoo group website, but for some reason
that particular attachment wasn't listed.


>
> 2) I had a few issues that might be specific to UnityNEAT.

Designing fitness functions is hard.They will tend to get stuck if the
'fitness landscape' has local maximums that are hard to escape from.
It's a problem and one of the issues still being researched, e.g.
novelty search.

> DropOff age might help, but I wasn't able to find it anywhere in the code.

Hmm, not sure where you got 'DropOff age' from(?) I think that was a
setting in SharpNEAT v1.x era code. In SharpNEAT 2.x genomes with the
same fitness but different ages are sorted so that the oldest ones are
removed from the population ahead of the newer ones.

Also check to see if SharpNEAT is in 'simplifying' mode for long
periods of time, if so you might want to try disabling phased
searching, which you can do by using the
NullComplexityRegulationStrategy class.

Also have you tried something like:

     log(1+myHits) + log(1+myDodge) + log(1+myBlocks)

or maybe

     log(1+myHits+myDodge+myBlocks)

Log is a natural choice because game scores are typically non-linear
with skill level - i.e. e.g. slightly more skill means you always win
and get all the points, versus always losing and never getting any
points.

I would also try not including the opponent's metrics in the fitness,
that adds an arbitrary factor into the scoring of the genome your are
scoring, unless it's a fixed opponent with consistent behaviour (i.e.
not another genome), but still worth trying out either way.

Colin
